Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: It'll probably not be what it once was, but there is plenty of value to recover here. They're in the black in actuality, they pay their debts, and much of this "provisioning money" they'll likely end up keeping. On top of which with Obama re-elected we can expect many of the loan portfolio come back to life at reduced rates that will at least be paid. Add a slow but steady economic recovery and I don't see what this isn't a bigtime longterm hold. Ask me they're finding every single loss or provisioning statute they can find and are cramming in the tax credits and burying cash as fast as they can. That's the way I'd be playing this economy with those kind of assets to protect. With MY kind of assets to protect I can afford to take on higher risk with the expectation of higher reward, one reason this property is so incredibly attractive, because if we DO tumble into a depression, then this stock is belly button lint.
I think this is the bottom for this stock, writing off the trash and beefing up the balance sheet
buyers are coming

I agree that it is a good question and your point about deleveraging further is certainly valid but I would gladly give up the 2.5 cents a quarter so they can focus on becoming a better brokerage firm. One of the impressive things, in my mind anyway, is that they preserved the brand in a terrible period of time. They not only need to upstream the cash but they need to sell the loan portfolio outright when possible.

Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: Agree that the odds are that they will have provisions for years to come but it isn't coming close to "killing them." I don't care what the news reports say but so far the vast majority of them don't even mention that it was a one-time special charge relating to retirement of debt that drove them into a loss position. That is over; they are going to be very profitable going forward.

Topic.Title: Any Reason To Hold This Stock

Message.Msg: Conceivable the loan loss reserves could decline (with negative provisions) but I judge that to be a fairly low odds scenario. Much lower provisions, lower reserves as the loans are being paid down fairly quickly but I don't consider it to be a possible positive; just that it will no longer be a drag.

Omega has been trimming its position for 2 quarters now. Last quarter they took it down by 30%. Leon is fed up with the lack of execution from these guys. They wait until now to cut 100mil in expenses and de-leverage the company? Citadel owned 30% of this stock and that is now down to 9.9% as Kenny is in the same boat and stuck for now. This has been a class study on excessive executive compensation and little to no insider ownership (managers). These dopes who have managed this company (VP's etc.) for years won't buy the stock with their money at $8 per share, then why should anyone else? They sit back and cash checks on shareholders backs while the stock gets hammered.

"Lack of inside ownership" Always an interesting topic. Obviously one always prefers to see executives buying and it indicates the shares aren't terribly cheap but what if they are just slightly below fair value? Would you tie up your net worth in your employer in that situation? I wouldn't as the risks are just too great and I know that the experts would say don't do it even if the shares were cheap. Also, the fact is that it is easy to get a distorted view when you are inside a company as you are just so focused on dealing with the problems of your own area due to time pressure as well as the fact that we are a society whose wealth is largely the result of combining the efforts of large numbers of people who have specialized in one little area, not broad high level review. So it ain't cheap but at least it isn't expensive. What I think anyway.

Now, I will agree with the premise of not having all of your money tied up in your own company's stock. See Enron as an example. Having a small part of your portfolio invested in the company you work for would not be excessive. I would think it would be prudent, since you have better/more accurate information about the prospects. Besides, I am not talking about some guy/girl working the phones at Etrade. I am talking about guys/girls who make 1 plus mil per year. Would it kill them to buy 10k shares in the 7/8 range once in a while? You would have to think that would not be sticking your neck out in a huge way. This company is not that complicated. The most difficult part is the servicing of the mortgage portfolio and they farm that out entirely....at a huge cost.

They have plenty of money to sent back to their beloved Meheco, but walk out of the emergency rooms and pay nothing toward their healthcare...and you have dopes on this board that think that just fine. **more than $91 million for illegal immigrant care over that period** Reports: Federal government paid $120M in Medicare services for prisoners, illegal immigrants MIAMI — The taxpayer-funded Medicare program paid more than $120 million from 2009 to 2011 in violation of federal law for medical services for inmates and illegal immigrants, according to two reports issued Thursday by federal health officials. Under federal law, Medicare generally does not pay for services for either group of patients. But the program was billed for more than $33 million in inmate care and more than $91 million for illegal immigrant care over that period, according to the reports from the Department of Health and Human Services inspector general.

Message.Title: FED balance sheet now tops 3 trillion
Message.Msg: **The Federal Reserve’s balance sheet now tops $3 trillion, a new record. The Fed has increased its purchases of Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities as part of its so-called quantitative easing strategy to revitalize the economy** We now have had the best week since 2004, are most folks better off today than they were then. When the government subsiditzies something you get more of it, and the FED is subsidizing the markets. What will happen when the fed quits stoking the QE...high rates and inflation as they try to unwind their balance sheet...enjoy it why it last. As the song by Dire Straits goes, "free money for nothing, and chicks for free"

Message.Title: Wear Dem Jobs At?
Message.Msg: If you had some talent and some drive, you could live the good life. Now, you need a lot of talent, a lot of drive and a lot of luck, and you probably will not have it as good as before. Diminished expectations are the Obama legacy

Etrade is a real disaster for me. Impartially looking at this, I will say that the calls for Feb, March and April are so cheap for $11. So the best play is to buy naked calls, to sell puts, and sell existing stocks. Last Dec, I had huge number of puts accumulated, but had to clear them to generate a huge loss so as to offset a huge gain from the flipping of real estate properties. It was a pain to see quite a bit lost with closing the puts early since majority of the closed sold puts could be at the breakeven point by now. Maybe this quarter is different. The real estate bidding war is raging on. You see a price hike of 30k plus in the last few months already. The effect will be seen by April this year.

Message.Title: Cry baby blacks
Message.Msg: This is why employers are reluctant to hire blacks, if they can't make it on merit they sue. If they had a criminal record they should have divulged it up front...then again, I quess they fiqured everyone does. **set out to humiliate them by making them audition and then disqualifying them due to their criminal records.** American Idol Racism Row: Nine Black Rejects Sue Fox ShowArticle Nine former contestants are taking legal action against American idolclaiming that they were forced off the show because of their race. American Idol is at the centre of a racism row after nine black former contestants claimed that they were all forced off the show as part of a racist plan to boost ratings. The singers, from various seasons, are preparing to take legal action against the hit talent show which they say "permanently and severely impaired" their personal and professional lives. Corey Clark, Jaered Andrews, Donnie Williams, brothers Terrell Brittenum and Derrell Brittenum,Thomas Daniels, Akron Watson, Ju'Not Joyner and Chris Golightly insisted that they were targeted by producers of the Fox show who set out to humiliate them by making them audition and then disqualifying them due to their criminal records.
